world_news:
• [Nov 25, 11:00 AM] European Union Climate Summit: Leaders of the 27 EU member states have gathered in Brussels for an emergency summit to discuss the bloc's response to the ongoing energy crisis and to reaffirm their commitment to the green transition.
  • [Nov 25, 9:30 AM] Asian Markets Rally: Stock markets across Asia saw a significant surge this morning, following the announcement of a new trade agreement between Japan and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
  • [Nov 25, 8:00 AM] Tensions in the South China Sea: The Philippines has lodged a diplomatic protest with Beijing after a Chinese coast guard vessel allegedly harassed a Filipino fishing boat near the disputed Scarborough Shoal.
  • [Nov 25, 5:00 AM] African Union Health Initiative: The African Union has launched a new continent-wide initiative to combat the spread of infectious diseases, with a focus on strengthening healthcare infrastructure and local vaccine production.
  • [Nov 25, 2:00 AM] Protests in Argentina: Thousands of protestors have taken to the streets of Buenos Aires to demonstrate against the government's latest austerity measures, which were introduced to tackle the country's soaring inflation.
  • [Nov 24, 10:00 PM] Canadian Parliament Approves New Carbon Tax: The Canadian government has passed a new bill that will increase the country's carbon tax by 15% over the next two years, as part of its efforts to meet its climate targets.
  • [Nov 24, 7:00 PM] Breakthrough in Alzheimer's Research: Scientists at a research institute in Switzerland have announced a major breakthrough in the development of a new drug that has shown significant promise in slowing the progression of Alzheimer's disease.
  • [Nov 24, 4:23 PM] US-China Relations: US President Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping held a phone call, where Trump described relations as 'extremely strong'. Xi reiterated Beijing's position on Taiwan.
  • [Nov 24, 2:00 PM] United Nations Report on Global Food Security: The UN has released a new report warning that millions of people are at risk of famine due to a combination of climate change, conflict, and economic instability.
  • [Nov 24, 12:00 PM] New Ceasefire in Yemen: A new 72-hour ceasefire has been announced in Yemen, following weeks of intense fighting between Houthi rebels and the Saudi-led coalition.
us_news:
• [Nov 25, 8:05 AM] Ukraine Peace Plan: Ukrainian officials have agreed to the 'core terms' of a peace proposal from the Trump administration to end the war with Russia. A U.S. official confirmed the agreement, stating that some details are still being negotiated in Geneva. This development occurred as Russia launched a new wave of deadly attacks on Kyiv overnight, killing at least seven people.
  • [Nov 24, 7:11 PM] US-Venezuela Tensions: The U.S. has designated the Venezuelan group 'Cartel de los Soles' as a terrorist organization, escalating pressure on the nation. This comes as the top U.S. military officer, Gen. Dan Caine, visited American troops in Puerto Rico and on a Navy warship in the Caribbean on Monday [Nov 24] to assess the ongoing situation.
  • [Nov 24, 12:47 PM] Comey and James Cases Dismissed: A federal judge on Monday dismissed criminal cases against former FBI Director James Comey and New York Attorney General Letitia James. The judge ruled that the prosecutor, Lindsey Halligan, who was personally appointed by President Trump to investigate his adversaries, was unlawfully appointed to her role.
  • [Nov 25, 10:09 AM] Medicare Drug Price Negotiations: The U.S. government is expected to announce the first-ever negotiated prices for 15 of the most expensive prescription drugs covered under its Medicare health plan later this week. This is a key part of the Inflation Reduction Act aimed at lowering healthcare costs.
  • [Nov 24, 8:00 AM] USPS Shipping Rates Increase: The United States Postal Service has announced it will increase prices for its shipping services. The rate adjustments are planned to take effect in the new year to help the agency achieve financial stability.
  • [Nov 24, 4:53 PM] Naval Academy Commandant Fired: The U.S. Naval Academy fired its commandant of midshipmen, Capt. Gilbert Clark Jr., on Monday, less than six months after he assumed the role. The academy cited a “loss of confidence in his ability to effectively lead” as the reason for his dismissal.
  • [Nov 24, 7:44 PM] Protections for Burmese Nationals End: The Trump administration has terminated Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for nationals of Myanmar (formerly Burma). The decision, announced Monday, will affect nearly 4,000 residents who will lose their status on January 26 and could face deportation.
  • [Nov 24, 5:04 PM] Stock Market Rallies: The S&P 500 jumped 1.5% on Monday, marking one of its strongest performances since the summer. The rally was led by a significant surge in Alphabet's stock price, boosting the overall market.
  • [Nov 24, 10:12 AM] US-Backed Gaza Aid Group Halts Operations: The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, a U.S.-backed organization established as an alternative to the UN for distributing aid, announced on Monday it is shutting down its operations. The closure comes amid clashes and disagreements between Israel's military and its defense minister over aid distribution methods.
  • [Nov 24, 2:50 AM] Sudan General Rejects US-Led Ceasefire: Sudan's leading general, Abdel-Fattah Burhan, has rejected a ceasefire proposal put forth by U.S.-led mediators on Monday. He described the proposal as 'the worst yet' and accused the mediators of being biased in their efforts to end the ongoing conflict.

financial_news:
• [Nov 25, 7:00 AM PST] US 10-Year Treasury Yield: The US 10-Year Treasury yield fell towards 4% following the release of weak jobs data, reinforcing expectations for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut in December.
  • [Nov 25, 3:39 AM PST] Bitcoin Price: Bitcoin's price stabilized, showing signs that the recent intense selling pressure may be easing. The token steadied after a significant slide, offering some hope to crypto investors.
  • [Nov 25, 6:00 AM PST] Crypto Regulation: The South African Reserve Bank issued a warning, identifying crypto assets and stablecoins as a new and significant risk to the country's financial stability due to a lack of comprehensive regulations.
  • [Nov 25, 5:24 AM PST] Fintech & Crypto: Swedish fintech giant Klarna announced its plan to launch a U.S. dollar-backed stablecoin, marking a significant move into digital assets by a major payments company.
  • [Nov 24, 5:15 AM PST] Federal Reserve: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller signaled support for an interest-rate cut in December, suggesting the central bank could then adopt a meeting-by-meeting approach based on incoming economic data.
  • [Nov 24, 3:00 AM PST] Cryptocurrency Funds: Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) investing in Bitcoin are on track for their worst month of outflows since their launch, with investors pulling out $3.5 billion, indicating negative sentiment in the crypto market.
  • [Nov 24, 1:04 PM PST] Crypto Exchange News: Binance is facing a lawsuit from victims of the Oct. 7, 2023 Hamas attack under the Anti-Terrorism Act, alleging the platform facilitated crypto transactions for the group.
  • [Nov 24, 2:02 PM PST] Gold Price: Gold prices increased as traders solidified bets on a December interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve, driven by signs of a weakening labor market.
  • [Nov 24, 5:50 PM GMT] UK Market Close: London's FTSE 100 index closed lower on Monday, dragged down by losses in consumer staples and industrial stocks as investors awaited the government's upcoming budget.
  • [Nov 24, 8:42 AM PST] Russian Economic Outlook: A senior executive at Sberbank, Russia's largest lender, stated that the Russian economy is experiencing a 'continued cooling' and projects growth to remain around 1% for the next year.
